column2: Bunny, said Henrietta one morning, shortly after we had come into possession of the Gaster jewels, "how is your nerve?
column3: Bunny, said Henrietta one morning, shortly after we had come into possession of the Gaster jewels, "how is your nerve?

column2: Are you ready for a coup requiring a lot of it?"
column3: Are you ready for a coup requiring a lot of it?"

column2: Well, I replied, pluming myself a bit, "I don't wish to boast, Henriette, but I think it is pretty good.
column3: Well, I replied, pluming myself a bit, "I don't wish to boast, Henriette, but I think it is pretty good.

column2: I managed to raise twenty-seven hundred dollars on my own account by the use of it last night."
column3: I managed to raise twenty seven hundred dollars on my own account by the use of it last night."

column2: Indeed? said Henriette, with a slight frown.
column3: Indeed? said Henriette, with a slight frown.

column2: How, Bunny?	How, Bunny?
column3: true

column2: You know you are likely to complicate matters for all of us if you work on the side. What, pray, did you do last night?"
column3: You know you are likely to complicate matters for all of us if you work on the side. What, pray, did you do last night?"

column2: And then I unfolded to her the incidents of the night before when, by assuming at a moment's notice the position of valet to young Robertson de Pelt, the frisky young favorite of the inner set, I had relieved that high-flying young bachelor of fifteen hundred dollars in cash and some twelve hundred dollars worth of jewels as well.
column3: And then I unfolded to her the incidents of the night before when, by assuming at a moment's notice the position of valet to young Robertson de Pelt, the frisky young favorite of the inner set, I had relieved that high flying young bachelor of fifteen hundred dollars in cash and some twelve hundred dollars worth of jewels as well.

column2: I was spending the evening at the Gentlemen's Gentlemen's Club, I explained, "when word came over the telephone to Digby, Mr. de Pelt's valet, that Mr. de Pelt was at the Rockerbilts' and in no condition to go home alone.
column3: I was spending the evening at the Gentlemen's Gentlemen's Club, I explained, "when word came over the telephone to Digby, mr de Pelt's valet, that mr de Pelt was at the Rockerbilts' and in no condition to go home alone.

column2: It happened that it was I who took the message, and observing that Digby was engaged in a game of billiards, and likely to remain so for some time to come, I decided to go after the gentleman myself without saying anything to Digby about it.
column3: It happened that it was I who took the message, and observing that Digby was engaged in a game of billiards, and likely to remain so for some time to come, I decided to go after the gentleman myself without saying anything to Digby about it.

column2: Muffling myself up so that no one could recognize me, I hired a cab and drove out to the Rockerbilt mansion, sent in word that Mr. de Pelt's man was waiting for him, and in ten minutes had the young gentleman in my possession.
column3: Muffling myself up so that no one could recognize me, I hired a cab and drove out to the Rockerbilt mansion, sent in word that mr de Pelt's man was waiting for him, and in ten minutes had the young gentleman in my possession.

column2: I took him to his apartment, dismissed the cab, and, letting ourselves into his room with his own latch-key, put him to bed.
column3: I took him to his apartment, dismissed the cab, and, letting ourselves into his room with his own latch key, put him to bed.

column2: His clothes I took, as a well-ordered valet should, from his bed-chamber into an adjoining room, where, after removing the contents of his pockets, I hung them neatly over a chair and departed, taking with me, of course, everything of value the young gentleman had about him, even down to the two brilliant rubies he wore in his garter buckles.
column3: His clothes I took, as a well ordered valet should, from his bed chamber into an adjoining room, where, after removing the contents of his pockets, I hung them neatly over a chair and departed, taking with me, of course, everything of value the young gentleman had about him, even down to the two brilliant rubies he wore in his garter buckles.

column2: This consisted of two handfuls of crumpled twenty-dollar bills from his trousers, three rolls of one-hundred-dollar bills from his waistcoat, and sundry other lots of currency, both paper and specie, that I found stowed away in his overcoat and dinner-coat pockets.
column3: This consisted of two handfuls of crumpled twenty dollar bills from his trousers, three rolls of one hundred dollar bills from his waistcoat, and sundry other lots of currency, both paper and specie, that I found stowed away in his overcoat and dinner coat pockets.

column2: There were also ten twenty-dollar gold pieces in a little silver chain-bag he carried on his wrist.
column3: There were also ten twenty dollar gold pieces in a little silver chain bag he carried on his wrist.

column2: As I say, there was about fifteen hundred dollars of this loose change, and I reckon up the value of his studs, garter rubies, and finger-rings at about twelve hundred dollars more, or a twenty-seven hundred dollars pull in all.
column3: As I say, there was about fifteen hundred dollars of this loose change, and I reckon up the value of his studs, garter rubies, and finger rings at about twelve hundred dollars more, or a twenty seven hundred dollars pull in all.

column2: Suppose he had recognized you?" cried Henriette.
column3: Suppose he had recognized you?" cried Henriette.

column2: Oh, he did--or at least he thought he did, I replied, smiling broadly at the recollection.

column2: On the way home in the cab he wept on my shoulder and said I was the best friend he ever had, and told me he loved me like a brother.	On the way home in the cab he wept on my shoulder and said I was the best friend he ever had, and told me he loved me like a brother.

column2: There wasn't anything he wouldn't do for me, and if ever I wanted an automobile or a grand-piano all I had to do was to ask him for it.
column3: There wasn't anything he wouldn't do for me, and if ever I wanted an automobile or a grand piano all I had to do was to ask him for it.

column2: He was very genial."

column2: Well, Bunny, said Henriette, "you are very clever at times, but do be careful.
column3: Well, Bunny, said Henriette, "you are very clever at times, but do be careful.

column2: I am delighted to have you show your nerve now and then, but please don't take any serious chances.
column3: I am delighted to have you show your nerve now and then, but please don't take any serious chances.

column2: If Mr. de Pelt ever recognizes you--and he dines here next Wednesday--you'll get us both into awful trouble."
column3: If mr de Pelt ever recognizes you-and he dines here next Wednesday-you'll get us both into awful trouble."

column2: Again I laughed.
column3: Again I laughed.

column2: He won't, said I, with a conviction born of experience.
column3: He won't, said I, with a conviction born of experience.

column2: His geniality was of the kind that leaves the mind a blank the following morning.	His geniality was of the kind that leaves the mind a blank the following morning.

column2: I don't believe Mr. de Pelt remembers now that he was at the Rockerbilts' last night, and even if he does, _you_ know that I was in this house at eleven o'clock."

column2: Why, I haven't seen you since dinner," she demurred.
column3: Why, I haven't seen you since dinner," she demurred.

column2: Nevertheless, Henriette, you know that I was in the house at eleven o'clock last night--or, rather, you _will_ know it if you are ever questioned on the subject, which you won't be, said I. "So, now that I have shown you in just what shape my nerve is, what is the demand you are going to put upon it?"

column2: You will have to bring to the enterprise all that ability which used to characterize your efforts as an amateur actor, Bunny, she replied. "Summon all your sang-froid to your aid; act with deliberation, courtesy, and, above all, without the slightest manifestation of nervousness, and we should win, not a petty little twenty-seven hundred dollars, but as many thousands.
column3: You will have to bring to the enterprise all that ability which used to characterize your efforts as an amateur actor, Bunny, she replied. column2: You know Mrs. Gushington-Andrews?"
column3: You know mrs Gushington Andrews?"

column2: Yes, said I. "She is the lady who asked me for the olives at your last dinner."
column3: Yes, said i "She is the lady who asked me for the olives at your last dinner."

column3: Precisely, observed Henriette.

column2: You possibly observed also that wherever she goes she wears about sixty-nine yards of pearl rope upon her person.
column3: You possibly observed also that wherever she goes she wears about sixty nine yards of pearl rope upon her person.

column3: Rope? I laughed.

column2: All pearls, Bunny, of the finest water, said Henriette, enthusiastically.
column3: All pearls, Bunny, of the finest water, said Henriette, enthusiastically.

column2: There isn't one of the thousands that isn't worth anywhere from five hundred to twenty-five hundred.
column3: There isn't one of the thousands that isn't worth anywhere from five hundred to twenty five hundred.

column2: And I am to land a yard or two of the stuff for you in some mysterious way? I demanded.
column3: And I am to land a yard or two of the stuff for you in some mysterious way? I demanded.

column2: How is it to be--by kidnapping the lady, the snatch and run game, or how?
column3: How is it to be-by kidnapping the lady, the snatch and run game, or how?

column2: Sarcasm does not suit your complexion, Bunny, retorted Henriette. "Your best method is to follow implicitly the directions of wiser brains.
column3: Sarcasm does not suit your complexion, Bunny, retorted Henriette. "Your best method is to follow implicitly the directions of wiser brains.

column2: You are a first-class tool, but as a principal--well--well, never mind.
column3: You are a first-class tool, but as a principal-well-well, never mind.

column2: You do what I tell you and some of those pearls will be ours.
column3: You do what I tell you and some of those pearls will be ours.

column2: Mrs. Gushington-Andrews, as you may have noticed, is one of those exceedingly effusive ladies who go into ecstasies over everything and everybody.
column3: mrs Gushington Andrews, as you may have noticed, is one of those exceedingly effusive ladies who go into ecstasies over everything and everybody.

column2: She is what Raffles used to call a palaverer.
column3: She is what Raffles used to call a palaverer.

column2: Where most people nod she describes a complete circle with her head.
column3: Where most people nod she describes a complete circle with her head.

column2: When a cold, formal handshake is necessary she perpetrates an embrace, and that is where we come in.
column3: When a cold, formal handshake is necessary she perpetrates an embrace, and that is where we come in.

column2: At my next Tuesday tea she will be present.
column3: At my next Tuesday tea she will be present.

column2: She will wear her pearls--she'll be strung with them from head to foot.
column3: She will wear her pearls-she'll be strung with them from head to foot.

column2: A rope-walk won't be in it with her, and every single little jewel will be worth a small fortune.
column3: A rope walk won't be in it with her, and every single little jewel will be worth a small fortune.

column2: You, Bunny, will be in the room to announce her when she arrives.
column3: You, Bunny, will be in the room to announce her when she arrives.

column2: She will rush to my arms, throw her own about my neck, the ornaments of my corsage will catch the rope at two or more points, sever the thread in several places, pearls will rain down upon the floor by dozens, and then--"
column3: She will rush to my arms, throw her own about my neck, the ornaments of my corsage will catch the rope at two or more points, sever the thread in several places, pearls will rain down upon the floor by dozens, and then-"

column2: I'm to snatch 'em and dive through the window, eh? I interrupted.
column3: I'm to snatch 'em and dive through the window, eh? I interrupted.

column2: No, Bunny--you will behave like a gentleman, that is all, she responded, haughtily; "or rather like a butler with the instincts of a gentleman.
column3: No, Bunny-you will behave like a gentleman, that is all, she responded, haughtily; "or rather like a butler with the instincts of a gentleman.

column3: At my cry of dismay over the accident-"

column3: At my cry of dismay over the accident," Henriette repeated, "you will spring forward, go down upon your knees, and gather up the jewels by the handful.

column2: You will pour them back into Mrs. Gushington-Andrews's hands and retire.

column2: Now, do you see?"

column2: H'm--yes, said I. "But how do you get the pearls if I pour them back into her hands?

column2: Am I to slide some of them under the rugs, or flick them with my thumb-nail under the piano--or what?"

column2: Instinct will carry you through the rest of it.

column2: The following Tuesday at five the second of Mrs. Van Raffles's Tuesday afternoons began.
column3: The following Tuesday at five the second of mrs Van Raffles's Tuesday afternoons began.

column2: Fortune favored us in that it was a beautiful day and the number of guests was large.
column3: Fortune favored us in that it was a beautiful day and the number of guests was large.

column2: Henriette was charming in her new gown specially imported from Paris--a gown of Oriental design with row upon row of brilliantly shining, crescent-shaped ornaments firmly affixed to the front of it and every one of them as sharp as a steel knife.
column3: Henriette was charming in her new gown specially imported from Paris-a gown of Oriental design with row upon row of brilliantly shining, crescent shaped ornaments firmly affixed to the front of it and every one of them as sharp as a steel knife.

column2: I could see at a glance that even if so little as one of these fastened its talons upon the pearl rope of Mrs. Gushington-Andrews nothing under heaven could save it from laceration.
column3: I could see at a glance that even if so little as one of these fastened its talons upon the pearl rope of mrs Gushington Andrews nothing under heaven could save it from laceration.

column2: What a marvellous mind there lay behind those exquisite, childlike eyes of the wonderful Henriette!
column3: What a marvellous mind there lay behind those exquisite, childlike eyes of the wonderful Henriette!

column2: Remember, Bunny--calm deliberation--your gloves now, were her last words to me.
column3: Remember, Bunny-calm deliberation-your gloves now, were her last words to me.

column3: Just watch me," she replied.

column2: Whereupon this wonderful creature, taking my white gloves, deliberately smeared their palms and inner sides of the fingers with a milk-hued paste of her own making, composed of talcum powder and liquid honey. column3: Whereupon this wonderful creature, taking my white gloves, deliberately smeared their palms and inner sides of the fingers with a milk hued paste of her own making, composed of talcum powder and liquid honey. column2: There! she said--and at last I understood.
column3: There! she said-and at last I understood.

column2: An hour later our victim arrived and scarce an inch of her but shone like a snow-clad hill with the pearls she wore.
column3: An hour later our victim arrived and scarce an inch of her but shone like a snow clad hill with the pearls she wore.

column2: I stood at the portiere and announced Mrs. Gushington-Andrews in my most blase but butlerian tones.

column2: The lady fairly rushed by me, and in a moment her arms were about Henriette's neck.

column2: You dear, sweet thing! cried Mrs. Gushington-Andrews.
column3: You dear, sweet thing! cried mrs Gushington Andrews.

column2: And you look so exquisitely charming to-day--
column3: And you look so exquisitely charming to day-

column2: The two women started to draw away from each other; five of the crescents catching in the rope, in the impulsive jerking back of Mrs. Gushington-Andrews in order that she might gaze into Henrietta's eyes, cut through the marvellous cords of the exquisite jewels.
column3: The two women started to draw away from each other; five of the crescents catching in the rope, in the impulsive jerking back of mrs Gushington Andrews in order that she might gaze into Henrietta's eyes, cut through the marvellous cords of the exquisite jewels.

column2: Well, Bunny, said Henriette, breathlessly, two hours later when her last guest had gone.

column2: Tell me quickly--what was the result?

column2: A good afternoon's work, I added.
column3: A good afternoon's work, I added.

column2: And, egad, it was: seventeen pearls of a value of twelve hundred dollars each, fifteen worth scarcely less than nine hundred dollars apiece, and some twenty-seven or eight smaller ones that we held to be worth in the neighborhood of five hundred dollars each.
column3: And, egad, it was: seventeen pearls of a value of twelve hundred dollars each, fifteen worth scarcely less than nine hundred dollars apiece, and some twenty seven or eight smaller ones that we held to be worth in the neighborhood of five hundred dollars each.

column2: Splendid! cried Henrietta "Roughly speaking, Bunny, we've pulled in between forty and fifty thousand dollars to-day."
column3: Splendid! cried Henrietta "Roughly speaking, Bunny, we've pulled in between forty and fifty thousand dollars to day."

column2: [Illustration: "I, OF COURSE, DID NOT TELL HENRIETTE OF EIGHT BEAUTIES I HAD KEPT OUT"]

column2: About that, said I, with an inward chuckle, for I, of course, did not tell Henriette of eight beauties I had kept out of the returns for myself.
column3: About that, said I, with an inward chuckle, for I, of course, did not tell Henriette of eight beauties I had kept out of the returns for myself.

column2: But what are we going to do when Mrs. Gushington-Andrews finds out that they are gone?
column3: But what are we going to do when mrs Gushington Andrews finds out that they are gone?

column2: I shall provide for that, said this wonderful woman.
column3: I shall provide for that, said this wonderful woman.
